Ultimately, a response will be given by the node whose address is given in the Request or Probe, but often a router or another node may be able to respond from their own table of addresses. An AARP Request with no corresponding AARP Response means that the AppleTalk address given is deemed to be unreachable.

PSpec.Name: Probe
PSpec.Desc: The AARP Probe is broadcast with a node's tentative choice for its address. If there is no AARP Response to the Probe after a certain amount of time, the Probe is sent out again and this sequence is repeated for a maximum number of retries. If no responses are ever received, the address is assumed to be available and will subsequently be adopted by that node. If the tentative address is already in use, the node which is using the tentative address must send an AARP Response packet. The original node, having received the Response, chooses a different tentative address. AARP Probes usually appear when a networked computer is first tries to join the AppleTalk internet.

PSpec.Name: Cisco FabricPath
PSpec.Desc: Cisco FabricPath is a proprietary implementation of TRILL (Transparent Interconnection of Lots of Links) that utilizes IS-IS for Layer 2 routing that is an alternative to Spanning Tree Protocol (STP).

PSpec.Name: Cisco Meta Data
PSpec.Desc: Cisco Meta Data is a component of Cisco TrustSec security architecture.

PSpec.Name: IEEE 802.3
PSpec.Desc: 802.3 is a comprehensive standard for Local Area Networks employing the Carrier Sense Multiple Access with Collision Detection (CSMA/CD) access method. Under the International Standards Organization (ISO) the 10 megabits per second transmission speed is specified by ISO/DIS 8802/3. The definition of Ethernet under 802.3 supersedes the previous Ethernet standard known as Ethernet Type 2. In terms of data bytes in the protocol stack, 802.3 uses bytes 13 and 14 as a length field, whereas the earlier standard used these bytes as a protocol definition field.

PSpec.Name: IEEE 802.11
PSpec.Desc: 802.11 is a comprehensive standard for Wireless Local Area Networks employing the Carrier Sense Multiple Access with Collision Avoidance (CSMA/CA) access method.

PSpec.Name: 802.11 Control
PSpec.Desc: 802.11 Control Frames assist with the delivery of Data & Management frames.

PSpec.Name: Block Ack Request
PSpec.Desc: At the end of a burst the sender transmits a block-ACK Request frame, the receiver replies with a Block ACK frame containing the status of reception.

PSpec.Name: Block ACK
PSpec.Desc: Block acknowledgments increase efficiency by aggregating the ACKs for multiple received frames into a single response. The implementation of block acknowledgment is optional.

PSpec.Name: PowerSave-Poll
PSpec.Desc: Stations in power save mode awaken periodically to listen to selected Beacons. If they hear that data is waiting for them, they will awake more fully and send a PS-Poll packet to the access point (BSS) to request the transmission of this waiting data. The Duration/ID field contains the Association ID (AID) for the station sending the packet.

PSpec.Name: Request to Send
PSpec.Desc: Request To Send packets help coordinate access to airwaves.

PSpec.Name: Clear to Send
PSpec.Desc: A Clear To Send packet is sent in response to a Request To Send. Helps coordinates access to airwaves.

PSpec.Name: Acknowledgment
PSpec.Desc: Acknowledges receipt of transmitted data.

PSpec.Name: Contention-Free End
PSpec.Desc: Signals the end of Contention Free period.

PSpec.Name: CF-End+CF-Ack
PSpec.Desc: Signals the end of the Contention Free period and Acknowledges the receipt of transmitted data in a single message.

PSpec.Name: Beamforming Report Poll
PSpec.Desc: To retrieve additional feedback from the second and subsequent beamformees, the beamformer must use a Beamforming Report Poll frame

PSpec.Name: Reserved Control Frame Extension
PSpec.Desc: IEEE 802.11 reserved frame type.

PSpec.Name: Poll
PSpec.Desc: IEEE 802.11 Control Extension Poll Frame.

PSpec.Name: SPR
PSpec.Desc: A IEEE 802.11 Control Extension SPR Frame.

PSpec.Name: Grant
PSpec.Desc: IEEE 802.11 Control Extension Grant Frame.

PSpec.Name: DMG CTS
PSpec.LName: 802.11 Control Frame Extension - DMG Clear To Send
PSpec.Desc: IEEE 802.11 Control Extension DMG Clear To Send Frame.

PSpec.Name: DMG DTS
PSpec.Desc: IEEE 802.11 Control Extension DMG DTS Frame.

PSpec.Name: Grant Ack
PSpec.Desc: IEEE 802.11 Control Extension Grant Ack Frame.

PSpec.Name: SSW
PSpec.Desc: IEEE 802.11 Control Extension Sector Sweep Frame.

PSpec.Name: SSW-Feedback
PSpec.Desc: IEEE 802.11 Control Extension Sector Sweep-Feedback Frame.

PSpec.Name: SSW-Ack
PSpec.Desc: IEEE 802.11 Control Extension Sector Sweep-Ack Frame.

PSpec.Name: Control Wrapper
PSpec.Desc: The Control Wrapper frame is used to carry any other control frame, other than another Control Wrapper frame together with a HT Control field.

PSpec.Name: Trigger
PSpec.Desc: A Trigger frame allocates resources for and solicits one or more HE TB PPDU transmissions. The Trigger frame also carries other information required by the responding STA to send an HE TB PPDU.

PSpec.Name: 802.11 Management
PSpec.Desc: There are 11 distinct management frame types. All management frames include fields: frame control duration address 1, 2, and 3, sequence control, frame body and frame check sequence. The frame body carries information in both fixed fields and in variable length information elements. Management frames in 802.11: beacon, probe request and response, authentication, deauthentication, association request and response, reassociation request and response, disassociation, and announcement traffic indication message.

PSpec.Name: Association Req
PSpec.Desc: An Association Request is sent to an access point (in a BSS or ESS) or to any other peer (in an IBSS or ad hoc network). The sender must already be authenticated in order to gain a successful association.

PSpec.Name: Association Rsp
PSpec.Desc: An Association Response is sent from an access point (in a BSS or ESS) or from any other peer (in an IBSS or ad hoc network) in response to an Association Request packet. If the request is successful, the response will include the Association ID of the requester.

PSpec.Name: Reassociation Req
PSpec.Desc: Similar to an Association Request, but it includes information about the current association at the same time as it requests a new association (either with the original Station after some lapse of time, or with a new station upon moving from one BSS to another). This packet is sent to an access point (in a BSS or ESS) or to any other peer (in an IBSS or ad hoc network). The sender must already be authenticated in order to gain a successful association.

PSpec.Name: Reassociation Rsp
PSpec.Desc: Similar to an Association Response, but in response to a Reassociation Request. This packet is sent from an access point (in a BSS or ESS) or from any other peer (in an IBSS or ad hoc network) in response to a Reassociation Request packet. If the request is successful, the response will include the Association ID of the requester.

PSpec.Name: Probe Req
PSpec.Desc: A Probe Request is used to actively seek any, or a particular, access point or BSS.

PSpec.Name: Probe Rsp
PSpec.Desc: A Probe Response is a reply to a Probe Request with station parameters and supported data rates.

PSpec.Name: Timing Adv
PSpec.Desc: A Timing Advertisement.

PSpec.Name: Beacon
PSpec.Desc: Beacon packets are sent by the access point in a BSS (or its equivalent in an IBSS) to announce the beginning of a Contention Free period (CF), during which the right to transmit is conferred by the access point by polling. Beacon management packets carry BSS timestamps to help synchronize member stations with the BSS, and other information to help them locate and choose the BSS with the best signal and availability.

PSpec.Name: ATIM
PSpec.Desc: An Announcement Traffic Indication Message packet serves much the same function in an IBSS that the Beacon packet does in an infrastructure (BSS or ESS) topology. The packet sets the synchronization of the group and announces that messages are waiting to be delivered. Stations in Power Save mode wake up periodically to listen for ATIM packets in ad hoc (IBSS) networks, just as they do for Beacon packets in infrastructure (BSS or ESS) networks.

PSpec.Name: Disassociation
PSpec.Desc: This packet is an announcement breaking an existing association. It is a one-way communication (meaning it does not require or accept a reply), and must be accepted. It can be sent by any associated station or BSS and it takes effect immediately.

PSpec.Name: Authentication
PSpec.Desc: Authentication packets are sent back and forth between the station requesting authentication and the station to which it is attempting to assert its authentic identity. The number of packets exchanged depends on the authentication method employed. Information relating to the particular scheme is carried in the body of the Authentication packet.

PSpec.Name: Deauthentication
PSpec.Desc: A Deauthentication packet is an announcement stating that the receiver is no longer authenticated. It is a one-way communication from the authenticating station (a BSS or functional equivalent), and must be accepted. It takes effect immediately.

PSpec.Name: TDLS Discovery Response
PSpec.Desc: Defined by the IEEE 802.11z specification, Tunneled Direct Link Setup is used to optimize traffic flow in a network and to directly transfer data between two WiFi clients that are part of the same WiFi network, while maintaining the connection with the AP.

PSpec.Name: Action
PSpec.Desc: The Action field provides a mechanism for specifying extended management actions.

PSpec.Name: Action No Ack
PSpec.Desc: The Action field provides a mechanism for specifying extended management actions.

PSpec.Name: 802.11 Data
PSpec.Desc: The simple data frame encapsulates the upper layer protocol packets delivering them from one IEEE 802.11 station to another. It may appear in both the contention period and the contention-free period.

PSpec.Name: 802.11 Fragment
PSpec.Desc: 802.11 data fragment.

PSpec.Name: 802.11 WEP Data
PSpec.Desc: WEP-encoded 802.11 data.

PSpec.Name: 802.11 Encrypted Data
PSpec.Desc: 802.11 data encrypted using either TKIP or CCMP

PSpec.Name: 802.11 A-MSDU
PSpec.Desc: Aggregate MSDU (A-MSDU) is formed by concatenating several MSDU's and intervening the sub-frame headers. All MSDUs within the A-MSDU must be addressed to the same receiver. A-MSDU can improve network efficiency because overhead associated with channel access is distributed over a much larger payload. A single A-MSDU may be up to 8 kbyte in length.

PSpec.Name: 802.11 Null Data
PSpec.Desc: 802.11 null function. Used when there is no data.

PSpec.Name: 802.11 TDLS Discovery Request
PSpec.Desc: Defined by the IEEE 802.11z specification, Tunneled Direct Link Setup is used to optimize traffic flow in a network and to directly transfer data between two WiFi clients that are part of the same WiFi network, while maintaining the connection with the AP.

PSpec.Name: 802.11 TDLS Setup Request
PSpec.Desc: Defined by the IEEE 802.11z specification, Tunneled Direct Link Setup is used to optimize traffic flow in a network and to directly transfer data between two WiFi clients that are part of the same WiFi network, while maintaining the connection with the AP.

PSpec.Name: 802.11 TDLS Setup Response
PSpec.Desc: Defined by the IEEE 802.11z specification, Tunneled Direct Link Setup is used to optimize traffic flow in a network and to directly transfer data between two WiFi clients that are part of the same WiFi network, while maintaining the connection with the AP.

PSpec.Name: 802.11 TDLS Setup Confirm
PSpec.Desc: Defined by the IEEE 802.11z specification, Tunneled Direct Link Setup is used to optimize traffic flow in a network and to directly transfer data between two WiFi clients that are part of the same WiFi network, while maintaining the connection with the AP.

PSpec.Name: 802.11 QoS Data
PSpec.Desc: 802.11 QoS is used to provide prioritized handling of WLAN traffic in order to improve the performance of time-sensitive applications such as VoIP, streaming media, and other similar applications. A number of mechanisms are used to implement 802.11 QoS. These are defined by the IEEE 802.11e specification.

PSpec.Name: 802.11 QoS Null Data
PSpec.Desc: 802.11 null function. Used when there is no data.

PSpec.Name: 802.11 QoS CF-Poll
PSpec.Desc: 802.11 QoS CF-Poll.

PSpec.Name: 802.11 QoS CF-Ack + CF-Poll
PSpec.Desc: 802.11 CF-Ack + CF-Poll.

PSpec.Name: DMG Beacon
PSpec.Desc: DMG Beacon.

PSpec.Name: S1G Beacon
PSpec.Desc: S1G Beacon.

PSpec.Name: Ethernet Type 2
PSpec.Desc: Ethernet Type 2 is the second version of Ethernet that was defined by Xerox Parc, Digital Equipment Corporation and other industry leaders around 1980 and was subsequently superseded by the international standard 802.3. Some protocols, such as IP and DECnet were originally defined under Ethernet Type 2, and have never successfully (in terms of widespread usage) migrated to the newer standard on Ethernet. In terms of data bytes on the wire, Ethernet Type 2 uses bytes 13 and 14 as a protocol definition field, whereas the later standard used these bytes as a length field.

PSpec.Name: WAN PPP
PSpec.Desc: The Point-to-Point Protocol (PPP) provides a standard method for transporting multi-protocol datagrams over point-to-point links. (RFC 1661)

PSpec.Name: Cisco SLARP
PSpec.LName: Cisco Serial Line Address Resolution Protocol
PSpec.Desc: SLARP is a router-to-router protocol that provides a method of dynamic address assignment as well as link-integrity verification.

PSpec.Name: Cisco SLARP
PSpec.LName: Cisco Serial Line Address Resolution Protocol
PSpec.Desc: SLARP is a router-to-router protocol that provides a method of dynamic address assignment as well as link-integrity verification.

PSpec.Name: WAN Frame Relay
PSpec.Desc: Frame Relay is a packet switching technology, which operates at the physical and data link layers of the OSI reference model. It specifies interfaces for connecting user devices to the network, as well as methods for addressing and transport through the network.

PSpec.Name: WAN X25
PSpec.Desc: X.25 is an ITU-T protocol standard for WAN that defines how connections between user devices and network devices are established and maintained.

PSpec.Name: WAN X25e
PSpec.Desc: WAN X.25 Modulo 128

PSpec.Name: WAN Ipars
PSpec.Desc: WAN Ipars

PSpec.Name: WAN U200
PSpec.Desc: WAN U200

PSpec.Name: WAN Q931
PSpec.Desc: WAN Q.931

PSpec.Name: NSH
PSpec.Desc: Imposed on packets or frames to realize Service Function Paths (SFPs). The NSH also provides a mechanism for metadata exchange along the instantiated service paths.
